				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CL: Breaking the Law: American Crime Stories											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-761256" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2016</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>Instructor: </strong>Nicholas Donofrio<br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 10-12</p>
<p><img height="134" width="162" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-07-18_at_11.48.37_am.png?m=1468856958&amp;itok=61dVPRh6" alt="" title="" />What is crime? Who commits it? When and where is it likely to occur? How should it be punished? And why do we find it so interesting? These are the questions at the dark heart of American crime fiction—questions whose answers have changed considerably over time. Course examines detective stories, spy novels, police procedurals, gangster movies, and more. Readings from Poe, Doyle, Christie, Hammett, and Highsmith; films include <em>Mildred Pierce</em>, <em>The Godfather</em>, and <em>Boyz n the Hood</em>.</p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/16959" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CM: Asian American Cultural Studies											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-761276" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2016</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Terry Park</span><br /><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 3-5</span></p>
<p><span style="font-size:small"><img height="127" width="162" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-07-18_at_11.52.53_am.png?m=1468857234&amp;itok=b4Pgw_nF" alt="" title="" />From yellow peril invaders to model minorities, Asian Americans have long been the indispensible threat and reliable punch line of U.S. popular culture. In response to these reductive constructions, Asian Americans have crafted their own dynamic cultural expressions in a number of media—from film, television, and music to fashion, sports, and food—that reveal the broad complexity of Asian America and contest the contradictions of the U.S. nation-state. Asian American culture also uniquely sits at the nexus of immigration flows and digital technologies, providing a transnational lens to view the US’s place in the world. This seminar, then, will introduce students to the study and practice of Asian American culture as heterogeneous, hybrid, and multiple. In doing so, students will gain an understanding of the shifting and interlocking tensions among the local, the national, and the global that form the cultural geographies of Asian America.</span></p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/16961" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CN: Poverty, Wealth, and Religion in the Middle Ages											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-761306" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Brian FitzGerald</span><br /><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 2-4</span></p><p><img height="103" width="162" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-11-29_at_5.48.53_pm.png?m=1480459856&amp;itok=aZ2jzapT" alt="" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This seminar considers the ethical, political, and spiritual questions arising from the existence of wealth and poverty, the rich and the poor, in medieval European culture.  What was the relationship between Christian charity and economic activity in the Middle Ages?  How did the religious values of a simple, austere life inform and conflict with changes in both Church and society?  Drawing on saints’ lives, theological treatises, art and architecture, and the work of poets such as Dante, Chaucer, and Shakespeare, the course will examine how the interaction of spiritual ideals and material realities shaped cultural developments and affected beliefs and practices from late antiquity to the Protestant Reformation.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CO: Latin American Cultural Criticism											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125076" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:carrasco@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">René Carrasco</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 4-6 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CO: Latin American Cultural Criticism" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90co_rc_latin_america.png?m=1501510799&amp;itok=o1BvLFGJ" title="" />This course will examine the world of ideas that has shaped Latin America. It is designed to provide students with the necessary tools to think critically about topics such as nationalism, capitalism, literary criticism, historiography, political and economic theory, identity politics, modernity, </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">colonialism/postcolonialism, gender, and many other topics that have shaped intellectual debates in Latin America and all over the world. We will labor at the intersection where literature, history, politics, theories and practices meet. This course will examine ideas and the practices they inform, as well as practices and the ideas that sustain them, as products of human culture that can be contested and changed. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CP: Boston and the World, 1600-1850											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125086" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:niles@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Alan Niles</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 2-4 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CP: Boston and the World" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cp_an_boston.png?m=1501511044&amp;itok=iKPAIzRF" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course studies Boston’s early history and literary culture. Our readings will feature prominent and influential authors such as John Winthrop, Anne Bradstreet, Samuel Adams, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, and Ralph Waldo Emerson. Our class activities and assignments </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">will involve travel around Cambridge and Boston to explore sites, museums, and archives. Throughout this course we will seek to understand how the Boston area’s distinct local culture has been shaped by global migration and exchange, from transatlantic Puritanism and Native American trade to the slave trade and Irish immigration. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CQ: Afro-Latin American Cultures: Race, Religion, Music, and Literature											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125096" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:rkennedylorenzini@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Rebecca A. Kennedy de Lorenzini</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 1-3 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CQ: Afro-Latin American Culture" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cq_rkl_afro_latin.png?m=1501511244&amp;itok=ZOiRuqAP" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course will explore the history of Afro-Latin American culture as expressed through literature, music, dance, and religious and spiritual practices. Beginning with an analysis of the theoretical framework of the African diaspora, we will ask central questions around how and why </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">African heritage has been celebrated or rendered invisible in Latin America. We will also consider where ideas of homeland and displacement shift with experiences of migration and in borderland regions. Themes of racialized and gendered experience will be discussed as well as systems of racism, oppression, cultural imperialism, and individual and collective agency within this history. The rich diversity of Afro-Latin American cultures will be highlighted in both the Caribbean and South America, as well as in sites of connection and convergence such as New York City, Havana, and Panamá. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CR: Narrative of Global Inequality											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125111" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:padler@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Paul K. Adler</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 3-5 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CR: Narratives of Global Inequality" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cr_pa_inequality.png?m=1501511394&amp;itok=xzc6TEV9" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">“More than one billion people in the world live on less than a dollar a day.” “For the past thirty years development policy has been dominated by the paradigm of export-led growth.” Sentences such as these epitomize how often we think of global economic inequalities in terms </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">of abstracted concepts. In this course, we will highlight another analytical lens: people's lives. Using films, novels, memoirs, and more, this course examines the history of attempts by everyone from sweatshop workers to presidents to create a more equitable global economy from the 1940s to the present. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CS: The Cultural Criticism of the Frankfurt School											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125126" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:acton@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Ryan Acton</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday/Thursday 5-6 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CS: The Cultural Criticism of the Frankfurt School" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cs_ra_frankfurt.png?m=1501511574&amp;itok=DaQlIJ8x" title="" /> The Frankfurt School was a group of intellectuals who first started writing in Germany in the tumultuous period between the two World Wars. They sought to understand why modernity had led not to progress, as earlier social theorists such as Marx had hoped, but to fascism, Stalinism, and an ever-more<!--break-->powerful capitalism. Where earlier Marxists had focused on economics and politics as the key sites of domination and resistance, the Frankfurt School turned to culture. Cultural forms such as radio, film, marriage, and even the concept of “free time,” they held, shaped people’s desires, beliefs, and hopes, reconciling them to a social order that hurt them. Unmasking culture’s complicity, the Frankfurt School believed, was not only a method for understanding the world but also a way of loosening domination’s grip. This course surveys some of the Frankfurt School’s most enduring works of cultural criticism. Topics include mass culture, aesthetics, sexuality, the psyche, politics, and critique.</span><br /> 
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CT: Deportation and the Policing of Migration in U.S. History											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125141" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:popeobeda@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Emily Pope-Obeda</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 11-1 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CT: Deportation and the Policing of Migration" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90ct_epo_deportation.png?m=1501511849&amp;itok=Me68oq2z" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course examines the history of deportation in American society, and considers how the policing, exclusion, and expulsion of immigrant populations has shaped the nation. Through historical texts, primary sources, literature, and popular culture, we will cover a wide range of topics including </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">racial quotas, guestworker expulsions, labor control, racialized health panics, national security scares, the disproportionate removal of black immigrants, the growth of immigrant detention, the criminalization of immigrant communities, and immigrant rights activism. Although mass deportation is often understood as a recent phenomenon, this course will demonstrate the ways that immigration control stretches as far back as creation of the United States. We will trace shifting opinions about immigration, the meaning of citizenship, statelessness, and national belonging. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CU: Fashion and Slavery											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125156" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:" style="text-decoration:none">Jonathan Square</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 2-4 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="139" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CU: Fashion and Slavery" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cu_js_fashion.png?m=1501512643&amp;itok=FiVKtqKp" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course examines the politics of fashion among people of African descent during slavery and the period immediately followed emancipation. Fashion is generative, yet underutilized analytic to explore the experience of the enslaved and their descendants. Geographical breadth is crucial to </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">examining the African Diaspora in its full complexity; therefore, course material will cover the United States, Caribbean, Latin America, and Africa. We will examine in particular the relationship between slave consumerism and the development of modern capitalism in the Atlantic World. Other topics of the course will include: sumptuary law, wealth accumulation among the enslaved and formally enslaved, honor and respectability politics, commodification of the enslaved, gendered sartorial expression, etc. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CV: Contemporary American Literature and Popular Music											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125161" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:awcorey@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Alex W. Corey</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 3-5</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="128" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CF: Contemporary American Literature and Popular Music" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cv_ac_music.png?m=1501512888&amp;itok=NUYITwuV" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This class examines the relationship between popular music, American literature, and the power structures that organize life in the United States. We will study the ways that music constructs social identities by considering how popular music—in performance, on record, and in written representation—</span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">can both reinforce and challenge hierarchies of gender, race, region, sexuality, class, and citizenship. Listening to recording artists such as Johnny Cash, Frank Ocean, Beyoncé, and Kendrick Lamar, we will learn how music plays a critical role in producing the social distinctions that popular culture is often presumed simply to reflect. Moreover, our study of literature by Alice Walker, Mary Gaitskill, Essex Hemphill, and others will show how the literary representation of sound can both articulate the pleasures and resist the injustices of an often-inadequate present moment.</span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-1125176 node-type-class og-context og-context-node og-context-node-362481 navbar-on">

    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CW: Great Migrations: Black Atlantic Travel Narratives											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125176" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:magloire@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Marina Magloire</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 3-5 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CW: Black Atlantic Travel Narratives" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cw_mm_migrations.png?m=1501513248&amp;itok=MTJWcfFJ" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">The story of the African diaspora begins with, and continues to be shaped by, travel. If, as Angela Davis posits, the ability to travel was one of the most significant ways that “emancipation radically transformed personal lives” of formerly enslaved people, this seminar seeks to consider </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">all of the ways that black people in the Americas exercised this newfound freedom in the twentieth century. This course begins with the narratives of enslaved Africans detailing their forced migration to the New World, and ends with the speculative black narratives of space travel and future utopias in which “walking while black” is no longer a crime. From the world travels of Harlem Renaissance intellectuals like Langston Hughes and Claude McKay, to the waves of decolonization that pushed black migrants to leave their homes in Africa and the Caribbean, this course explores the tensions between a fraught history of coerced migration and a tempting possibility of leisured wandering. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CX: Stop Making Sense: America in the 1980s											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125171" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:allan@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Angela S. Allan</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 1-3 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CX: America in the 1980s" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cx_aa_1980s.png?m=1501513091&amp;itok=B3rUvgrU" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">The 1980s saw the convergence of American politics and economics to strengthen U.S. interests abroad, but the decade was also a moment of enormous social, political, and economic divergence at home. How compatible—or causal—was the end of the cold war with the end of the American cultural </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">consensus? Did such a consensus ever exist, or was it a mere illusion and nostalgia for a “simpler time”? This course will look at how culture—including novels, films, plays, music videos, and more—both shapes and is shaped by social and political attitudes. As the 1980s experiences a pop culture comeback in the 2010s, how do we begin to critically make sense of a decade of contradictions? </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CY: Watergate: Conspiracy, Paranoia, and the Abuse of Power											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125441" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:biel@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Steve Biel</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 2-4 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CY: Watergate" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cy_sb_watergate.png?m=1501520288&amp;itok=BqcoG3Wp" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">Russiagate, Emailgate, Benghazigate: these are the latest in a series of scandals and pseudo-scandals bearing the suffix that originates in the name of the Washington hotel where, in the summer of 1972, burglars associated with the Committee to Re-Elect the President broke into the Democratic </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">National Committee headquarters. The subsequent cover-up and revelations of a myriad of crimes and abuses of power by the Nixon White House and previous administrations, abbreviated as “Watergate,” reshaped U.S. political culture in the 1970s and resonate into our own time. Corrupt power, secrecy, surveillance, and paranoia suffuse these works. In this course, we will explore how Watergate figured into canonical works of popular culture, especially Hollywood movies, in the first half of the 1970s. </span><span style="font-size:small">They speak to a pervasive distrust of American institutions—especially government—that extended across the political spectrum. Watergate will be our entry point into a wide-ranging engagement with the cultural history of the 1970s and its legacies in the present. Filmmakers and authors include Francis Ford Coppola, Sidney Lumet, Barbara Kopple, Alan J. Pakula, Ivan Dixon, Robert Altman, Roman Polanski, Martin Scorsese, Mary McCarthy, Elizabeth Drew, Kurt Vonnegut, Ursula K. LeGuin, Gore Vidal, Carl Bernstein, and Bob Woodward. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90CZ: Middle Eastern Displacements: From Ottoman Migrants to Syrian Refugees											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125451" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:pece@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Uğur Z. Peçe</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 2-4 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CZ: Middle Eastern Displacements" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cz_up_displacements.png?m=1501520480&amp;itok=_hO_S0Gx" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">The current humanitarian disasters in the Middle East and North Africa have brought the plight of refugees in the region to the fore. Taking a long-term historical perspective, this course explores the centrality of migrants and refugees to the formation of the modern Middle East. Drawing on multiple </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">cases of migration and displacement from the mid-nineteenth century to the present, we will investigate historical processes that resulted in the uprooting of diverse populations throughout the broader Middle East. Topics include war (inter-state and civil), population transfers and exchanges, voluntary and forced migration, assimilation and integration, and exile and memory. We will explore these themes by drawing on diverse primary sources such as fiction, poetry, memoirs, music, photography, and film. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
