		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90DA: Rock and Roll to Rap en Español: Urban Youth Cultures in América											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125471" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2018</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Melissa Castillo-Garsow<br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 3-5</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="139" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90DA: Urban Youth Cultures" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90da_mcg_youth.png?m=1501521311&amp;itok=aU1v89TC" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course explores the history of race relations, civil rights, and youth cultures post WWII through the lens of music history. Although overtime, African American contributions to American Music have become more and more recognized, Latino contributions to popular music in the United States have mostly </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">been relegated to the margins of a narrative dominat-ed by an overly black and white view of musical history. Latin music is often portrayed as an exotic resource for "American" musicians. Often seen as purely foreign music, this course turns that perspective on its head. We will document the roles of U.S. Latino musicians as interpreters of Latin American genres, as well as their roles as innovators within genres normally considered non-Latino music: R&amp;B, jazz, Rock &amp; Roll, country/western, punk and hip hop. In this course, we examine how the sensibility and musical creativity of urban youth, in very different historical periods, inspired musical revolutions which transformed the tastes of entire generations, crossing boundaries of race, gender, nation and social class. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90DB: Museums in America											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125491" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2018</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:gochberg@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Reed Gochberg</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 1-3</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90DB: Museums in America" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90db_rg_museums.png?m=1501524494&amp;itok=7OndOvav" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">In this course, we will consider the literary and cultural history of American museums from the eighteenth century to the present. Throughout the semester, we will discuss how museums have functioned as both centers for research and as public spaces for education and entertainment, and how </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">such priorities have evolved over the past few centuries, shaped by new ideas about conservation, education, and access. How do we determine the authenticity and value of art objects and natural specimens? How have museums informed debates over national politics and cultural authority? And how do museum collections create narratives about national and natural history? We will explore these and other questions through a range of sources, including fiction and poetry, visual and material culture, and periodicals and museum guidebooks, as well as visits to Harvard’s own varied museum collections and the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

  </div>
    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1423258810" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1423258810"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90DC: Colonialism as Madness											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125486" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2018</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:abattach@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Anouska Bhattacharyya</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 1-3</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90DC: Colonialism as Madness" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90dc_ab_colonialism.png?m=1501524198&amp;itok=6vbnMR4X" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">Why do we take the history of Euro-American psychiatry as the barometer against which we understand all other histories of madness? Is there a larger narrative of insanity that doesn’t use the Greenwich Meridian as the centre of the world? To give students the tools to answer </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">these questions, this course uses underutilized literature from South Africa, the Pacific Islands, and South Asia as the roots of a new kind of canon. Students will grapple with the history of madness in three registers -- individual, community, and transnational. Within these registers lies a more pressing issue: can we consider colonialism itself a form of madness? Students will unpack a historical and literary madness that removes the centrality of the Euro-American story and creates a global story where the ‘mad’ are not simply a racial ‘other’.</span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90DD: Women at War in France and in the Colonies											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125496" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2018</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:sevcik@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Stefanie Sevcik</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 10-12</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90DD: Women at War" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90dd_ss_france.png?m=1501524672&amp;itok=P3vyBk2H" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This seminar explores roles women have played in wars for independence across the French-speaking world. As the Italian director Gillo Pontecorvo depicts in his iconic film, The Battle of Algiers (1966), some women fought alongside men carrying bombs in the fight for freedom from the French in </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">Algeria. However, more often, women have forged their own paths parallel to men enacting complex forms of resistance through art, mobilizing domesticity, and protest. Using women in the French Revolution as our starting point, we will engage with women who resist the reductive fantasy of the female freedom fighter throughout the French-speaking world with an emphasis on the case of Algeria. Figures under our investigative lens include Olympe de Gouges who proclaimed a “Declaration of the Rights of Women” in France, Assia Djebar who depicted women playing new roles outside of the home in Algeria, and Lina Mhenni who used social media in Tunisia to show the world injustice taking place under a repressive regime in 2010. Alongside these memoirs, literary texts, historical documents, and films by and about women at war, we will develop a critical vocabulary of women at work reading theorists that include Karl Marx, Michel Foucault, Gayatri Spivak, and Judith Butler. Over the course of the semester, we will put these voices in conversation with one another in order to reconstruct alternative histories of resisting oppression in the francophone world and beyond. </span>
</p>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small">  </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL90L: Stories of Slavery and Freedom											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-1125516" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2018</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:timothy_mccarthy@hks.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Tim McCarthy</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 10-12</span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90L: Stories of Slavery and Freedom" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90l_tm_slavery.png?m=1501525329&amp;itok=XfELtFEX" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">In the last generation, scholars have revolutionized our understanding of slavery and freedom in the modern Atlantic world. This sea-change has been the result of a major methodological shift: to view this history through the eyes of slaves rather than the eyes of masters. This course will examine the </span><!--break--><span style="font-size:small">history of the "black Atlantic" through a diverse range of cultural texts--poetry, pamphlets, court cases, petitions, autobiographies, novels, speeches, and sermons--produced by slaves, free blacks, and abolitionists from the Age of Revolution to emancipation. </span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-620861 node-type-class og-context og-context-node og-context-node-362481 navbar-on">

    <a href="#main-content" class="element-invisible element-focusable" tabindex="1">Skip to main content</a>
  </div>
    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL97: Twentieth-Century Art and Politics Across the Atlantic											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-620861" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructors:</strong> <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/nickdonofrio" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Nick Donofrio</a> and </span><span style="font-size:small"><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/people/dean-dean-valencia-garc%C3%ADa" style="text-decoration:none">Louie Valencia</a></span><br /><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 2-5</span></p><p><img height="73" width="220" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/histlit/files/guernica.jpg?m=1480427911&amp;itok=9nz55iAi" alt="" title="" /><span style="font-size:12px">This course examines three moments of transatlantic cultural exchange and mirroring from the last century: the interwar years, when a series of economic, political, and military crises racked Europe and the United States, prompting radical experiments in social organization and artistic form; the aftermath of World War II, when an unlikely array of artists and intellectuals found themselves stationed on the front lines of the Cold War and a shifting coalition of movements challenged the “Free World” to live up to its name; and the long now of neoliberalism and globalization, linked developments that have generated new challenges and opportunities for the planet and its peoples—and for art and politics. As we analyze documentary photographs and state-sponsored art exhibitions, poems and plays, movies and manifestos, graphic novels and more, we will pay close attention to the artists, activists, scholars, and government officials who produced and distributed them, and to the publics who received them. We will see works of art deployed for all sorts of political purposes, some of which had very little to do with their creators’ intentions. Throughout, we will consider how art is shaped by the politics of race, class, gender, sexuality, and national identity, and how it shapes these things in turn.</span></p><p> </p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26276" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL97: The Work of Death											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-620846" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructors:</strong> <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/lbrandt" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Lauren Brandt</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/chopkins" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Caitlin Galante DeAngelis Hopkins</a><br /><strong>Meeting time:</strong> Thursday, 1-4</span></p><p><span style="font-size:small"><img height="148" width="152" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-01-12_at_1.36.39_pm.png?m=1452623873&amp;itok=eWUd_dDH" alt="" title="" />Everybody dies. Death is universal and inevitable, but how we experience it over time and how people have understood in the past and in the present differs according to time, place, location, ethnicity, race, religious belief, and many other cultural, political and social factors. This course examines the history of death in the American context, through a wide range of historical and literary sources. It is arranged in rough chronological order, but our emphasis throughout will be tracing how death has been used to categorize and shape people’s collective and individual identities. Each unit will provide opportunities for you to analyze a range of developments in history and literature – such as slavery, environmental history, political organization, and social protest – and a variety of textual genres including short stories, poetry, philosophy, journalism, photography, and cultural objects. </span></p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26275" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL97: London: World City											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-620866" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/abhattacharyya" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Anouska Bhattacharyya</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/dew" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Duncan White</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 12-3</span></p><p><span style="font-size:small"><img height="96" width="162" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/unnamed.jpg?m=1452705088&amp;itok=-MOeroJ1" alt="" title="" />This course is about the ways in which London shaped global culture, and the way global culture shaped it. We will consider how London became a world city in the Victorian era, and the ways in which this status was projected, from the Great Exhibition of 1851 to the 2012 Olympics. Through our reading of wide range of cultural forms, including novels, poems, films, graphic novels, photography, maps, posters, popular music, food and fashion, we will explore the city’s fluid identity, and the ways in which it was imagined by locals and visitors. In some weeks we focus on specific historical moments and in others take a more thematic approach but the overall goals will be the same: to understand how the city has been mythologized and reinvented by its rapidly changing population.</span></p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26271" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

<!--REGION TO HOUSE RESPONSIVE MENU. OTHER CONTENT CAN'T BE PLACED HERE-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes" >CLASSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												HL97: Utopias and Dystopias in U.S. and the World											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<article id="node-620871" class="node node-class article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/pauladler" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Paul Adler</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/mdalessandro" style="text-decoration:none" title="">Mike D’Alessandro</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 2-5</span></p><p><span style="font-size:small"><img height="124" width="169" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-01-12_at_4.18.55_pm.png?m=1452633654&amp;itok=r1eANdr9" alt="" title="" /></span></p><p><span style="font-size:12px">This class will examine the United States’ social, cultural, economic, and political dreams and nightmares from the turn of the twentieth century to speculative futures. We will do so from  transnational perspectives, discussing the utopias and dystopias imagined by writers of all backgrounds and views without incorporating how they found inspiration and terror in looking at other societies. We will investigate traditional examples of utopias and dystopias--from planned communes to futuristic totalitarian regimes--at the same time that we will test the boundaries of utopian and dystopian definitions.</span></p><p><span style="font-size:12px"> Throughout, we will ask  questions of these genres such as: how have utopian and dystopian stories illuminated fears around changing economic structures, gender dynamics, and race relations? In what ways do utopias and dystopias offer insight into ideals of individualism and fears of conformity? What aspects of United States history have unfolded as real-life utopias and dystopias? And how distinct are the concepts of utopia and dystopia? We will explore these questions through a wide range of texts, from novels to films to manifestos to plays to sermons.</span></p></div></div></div><section class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-above view-mode-full"><h2 class="field-label">Link:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26274" >Course website</a></div></div></section>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
									</div>
								
							</section><!--main content ends-->
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
						
													<section id="main-content">
								<a name="main-content"></a>
																									<header id="main-content-header">
																					<h1 id="page-title">
												Classes											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<div class="view view-os-classes view-id-os_classes view-display-id-page view-dom-id-60bbe0f324670b83a9b1aff74f05db15">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">
    <article id="node-1125126" class="node node-class node-teaser article clearfix" role="article">
  
      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cs-cultural-criticism-frankfurt-school-0" rel="bookmark">HL90CS: The Cultural Criticism of the Frankfurt School</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:acton@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Ryan Acton</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday/Thursday 5-6 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CS: The Cultural Criticism of the Frankfurt School" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cs_ra_frankfurt.png?m=1501511574&amp;itok=DaQlIJ8x" title="" /> The Frankfurt School was a group of intellectuals who first started writing in Germany in the tumultuous period between the two World Wars. They sought to understand why modernity had led not to progress, as earlier social theorists such as Marx had hoped, but to fascism, Stalinism, and an ever-more <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cs-cultural-criticism-frankfurt-school-0" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90CS: The Cultural Criticism of the Frankfurt School</span></a></span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:padler@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Paul K. Adler</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 3-5 </span>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CR: Narratives of Global Inequality" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cr_pa_inequality.png?m=1501511394&amp;itok=xzc6TEV9" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">“More than one billion people in the world live on less than a dollar a day.” “For the past thirty years development policy has been dominated by the paradigm of export-led growth.” Sentences such as these epitomize how often we think of global economic inequalities in terms </span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cr-narrative-global-inequality" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90CR: Narrative of Global Inequality</span></a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cq-afro-latin-american-cultures-race-religion-music-and-literature" rel="bookmark">HL90CQ: Afro-Latin American Cultures: Race, Religion, Music, and Literature</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Fall</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><strong>Instructor: </strong><a href="mailto:rkennedylorenzini@fas.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration:none">Rebecca A. Kennedy de Lorenzini</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 1-3 </span>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CQ: Afro-Latin American Culture" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cq_rkl_afro_latin.png?m=1501511244&amp;itok=ZOiRuqAP" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course will explore the history of Afro-Latin American culture as expressed through literature, music, dance, and religious and spiritual practices. Beginning with an analysis of the theoretical framework of the African diaspora, we will ask central questions around how and why </span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cq-afro-latin-american-cultures-race-religion-music-and-literature" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90CQ: Afro-Latin American Cultures: Race, Religion, Music, and Literature</span></a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

<p>
	<img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CP: Boston and the World" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cp_an_boston.png?m=1501511044&amp;itok=iKPAIzRF" title="" /><span style="font-size:small">This course studies Boston’s early history and literary culture. 	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="137" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CO: Latin American Cultural Criticism" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90co_rc_latin_america.png?m=1501510799&amp;itok=o1BvLFGJ" title="" />This course will examine the world of ideas that has shaped Latin America. 	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90CB: Environmental Change" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90cb_lf_environmental.png?m=1501510606&amp;itok=v7MWhvbQ" title="" />This course examines American environmental literature from the period of colonization through the era of climate change.  Our focus will be on how people from an array of different backgrounds experienced and inscribed North American environments.  </span> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90cb-environmental-change-american-literature-and-history" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90CB: Environmental Change in American Literature and History</span></a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><img height="138" width="161" style="float: left;" alt="HL90 BA: England After Empire" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/hl90ba_dw_england.png?m=1501510267&amp;itok=fSsHa7Ya" title="" />This course considers the way England was transformed by the demise of its empire after the Second World War.   <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Erin Pearson</span><br /><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 10-12</span></p><p><img height="122" width="161" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/capture_6.png?m=1480448392&amp;itok=uT3ENnbK" alt="" title="" /><span style="font-size: small;">This course asks how Americans have made sense of the Civil War.  It begins by investigating texts that reflect the</span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90ce-civil-war-american-imagination" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90CE: The Civil War in the American Imagination</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

    <article id="node-761281" class="node node-class node-teaser article clearfix" role="article">
  
      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90bg-colonization-globalization-and-cultures-asian-diasporas" rel="bookmark">HL90BG: Colonization, Globalization, and Cultures of Asian Diaspora(s)</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Genevieve Clutario</span><br /><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 2-4</span></p><p><img height="128" width="161" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-11-29_at_2.25.36_pm.png?m=1480447609&amp;itok=ouzDjLvt" alt="" title="" /><span style="font-size: small;">This course takes a cultural approach to historical developments of Asian diaspora, colonialism, and</span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90bg-colonization-globalization-and-cultures-asian-diasporas" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90BG: Colonization, Globalization, and Cultures of Asian Diaspora(s)</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-13 views-row-odd">
    <article id="node-620871" class="node node-class node-teaser article clearfix" role="article">
  
      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-utopia-and-dystopia-american-life" rel="bookmark">HL97: Utopias and Dystopias in U.S. and the World</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26274" >Course website</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/pauladler" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Paul Adler</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/mdalessandro" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Mike D’Alessandro</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 2-5</span></p><p><span style="font-size: small;"></span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-utopia-and-dystopia-american-life" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL97: Utopias and Dystopias in U.S. and the World</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-14 views-row-even">
    <article id="node-620866" class="node node-class node-teaser article clearfix" role="article">
  
      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-london-world-city" rel="bookmark">HL97: London: World City</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26271" >Course website</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/abhattacharyya" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Anouska Bhattacharyya</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/dew" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Duncan White</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 12-3</span></p><p><span style="font-size: small;"></span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-london-world-city" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL97: London: World City</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-15 views-row-odd views-row-last">
    <article id="node-620861" class="node node-class node-teaser article clearfix" role="article">
  
      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-american-art-and-politics" rel="bookmark">HL97: Twentieth-Century Art and Politics Across the Atlantic</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26276" >Course website</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructors:</strong> <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/nickdonofrio" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Nick Donofrio</a> and </span><span style="font-size: small;"><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/people/dean-dean-valencia-garc%C3%ADa" style="text-decoration: none">Louie Valencia</a></span><br /><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Thursday, 2-5</span></p><p></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-american-art-and-politics" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL97: Twentieth-Century Art and Politics Across the Atlantic</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
  </div>
    </div>
  
      <h2 class="element-invisible">Pages</h2><div class="item-list"><ul class="pager"><li class="pager-first"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes">first</a></li><li class="pager-previous"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes">«</a></li><li class="pager-item"><a title="Go to page 1" href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes">1</a></li><li class="pager-current">2</li><li class="pager-item"><a title="Go to page 3" href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes?page=2">3</a></li><li class="pager-item"><a title="Go to page 4" href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes?page=3">4</a></li><li class="pager-next"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes?page=2">»</a></li><li class="pager-last"><a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes?page=3">last</a></li></ul></div>

								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1434649112" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1434649112"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Worksheets &amp; Forms</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1434649112' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	The following advising tools help guide students in reflecting on their goals and the coherence of their individualized work in the concentration. Concentrators complete these forms in consultation with their tutors.
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-worksheets" style="text-decoration:none">Field Worksheets</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#POC-form" style="text-decoration:none">Plan of Concentration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#field-declaration-form" style="text-decoration:none">Field Declaration Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#modern-world-proposal" style="text-decoration:none">Modern World Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#subfield-form" style="text-decoration:none">Subfield Proposal Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#thesis-request" style="text-decoration:none">Senior Thesis Interests Form</a>
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms#petition" style="text-decoration:none">Petition Form</a>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Visit the <a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/forms" style="text-decoration:none">Forms</a> page for a step-by-step guide to these materials and their role in a student's progress through the concentration.
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

		  <div class="branding-left"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" ><img src="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/profiles/openscholar/themes/hwpi_basetheme/images/harvard-logo.png" width="235" height="32" alt="Harvard Logo" /></a></div><div class="branding-right"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" >HARVARD.EDU</a></div>		</div>

<div id="page" class="container page header-main header-right content-none footer footer-right">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1423258810" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1423258810"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1423258810' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/"><img height="66" width="475" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/histlit/files/hlbanner1.png?m=1435681341&amp;itok=YHiT_esd" alt="" title="" /></a></p></div></div></div>

        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26272" >Course website</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/schnepf" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Jen Schnepf</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/jamesstanley" style="text-decoration: none" title="">James Stanley</a><br /><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Wednesday, 1-4</span></p><p><span style="font-size: small;"></span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-imagining-media" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL97: Imagining Media</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">

        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-field-class-link field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/26270" >Course website</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructors: </strong><a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/tahtinen.harvard.edu" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Lauri Tahtinen</a> and <a href="http://scholar.harvard.edu/mtworek/home" style="text-decoration: none" title="">Michael Tworek</a></span><br /><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Tuesday, 1-4</span></p><p><span style="font-size: small;"></span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl97-home-and-away" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL97: Home and Away</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

      <header class="node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90br-silver-cocainecultures-commodity-production-across-americas" rel="bookmark">HL90BR: Cultures of Commodity Production Across the Americas</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <section class="field field-name-field-semester field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Semester:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Spring</div></div></section><section class="field field-name-field-offered-year field-type-datetime field-label-inline clearfix view-mode-teaser"><h2 class="field-label">Offered:&nbsp;</h2><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">2017</span></div></div></section><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Instructor: </strong>Frances P. Sullivan</span><br /><span style="font-size: small;"><strong>Meeting time: </strong>Monday, 1-3</span></p><p align="center" style="text-align: left;"><img height="127" width="161" style="float: left;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-small" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/histlit/files/screen_shot_2016-11-29_at_2.32.31_pm.png?m=1480448016&amp;itok=4nfmy5OU" alt="" title="" /><span style="font-size: small;">This seminar explores the history of Latin American and</span></p> <a href="https://histlit.fas.harvard.edu/classes/hl90br-silver-cocainecultures-commodity-production-across-americas" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about HL90BR: Cultures of Commodity Production Across the Americas</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>
